speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: We'll hear argument next in Case 05-1631, Scott versus Harris. Mr. Savrin.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Can I ask this question about the shopping center. Wouldn't your case be exactly the same if the shopping center incident had not occurred?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: So that we really don't have to get distracted by the shopping center?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I'm not sure why you concede that. I mean, I looked at the case and it seemed to me it's a case involving the whole ball of wax. And I suspect my reaction to that tape was in part affected by the fact that he went through the shopping center, came out and crashed into a police car, which is what Scott saw.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: So how do I know whether, which of these things is directly or not indirectly - - well, you go ahead. But I mean, are you -- am I not supposed to look at the part which involves the shopping center?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Is the rule that you propose that the policeman must balance the risk of harm to others versus the risk of harm to the fleeing person?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Your brief says that the officer reasonably believes that doing so, i.e., terminating the chase, would avoid a greater risk of bodily injury or death.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Greater than what? Greater than - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Without reference to the possible harm to the driver? I just want to know what you're testing.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I don't know that I agree with that. I mean, if this fellow driving 90 miles an hour is responsible for endangering people, you're proposing a rule that says if there's a 50 percent chance that he'll hurt some innocent person and a 50 percent chance that he'll get hurt if you try to stop him, you shouldn't do anything. I don't agree with that.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I'd stop him. I mean, he's the fellow that's causing the danger, endangerment, isn't he?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I think you're giving away too much.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: I didn't mean to put words in your mouth. It seems to me your test might be whether there is a greater risk in stopping him or not stopping him as to other people, without reference to the risk to himself.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, it's your brief. I want you to - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Well, isn't the speed also relevant to the likelihood that -- that running into a car at that speed would cause the death of a driver?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Isn't it a fair high probability that if you hit someone at that speed that there will be something, either death or serious injury as a result?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, I suppose there is also a high probability where you're going 90 miles an hour on a one-way road, crossing over the double yellow line, with oncoming traffic, that you're going to hurt somebody else.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I mean, the more you increase the speed the more likely he's going to be hurt. But also the more likely if you let him go somebody else is going to be hurt.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But Mr. Savrin, there was an episode in the parking lot where things came to a temporary halt. If Scott had stopped pursuing Harris at that point, maybe Harris would not -- maybe he would have slowed down. If he was -- he was trying to flee from the police, but if the police weren't after him there is no indication that he would have been speeding.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, he was speeding before the police knew about him, right? That's the whole, where this all started.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Well, do you contend that an officer can always use deadly force to stop a high-speed driver who's creating this kind of a risk?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Running into him with a high probability that he'll get killed.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Wasn't that acknowledged in the district court, in the trial court?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Yes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: But the jury might find that it was deadly force.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: And do you conclude that the jury could not find that it was deadly force?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Well, but is your -- is it your view that a jury could not find on these facts that there was deadly force?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: I thought we had a test for deadly force in Garner and it's whether or not there is -- it's more likely than not, whether or not there is a serious risk that death will ensue. That's the test, Garner.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: What test, what of deadly force would not be met here?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Considering that it's a summary judgment issue.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Finish that.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Excuse me. He reasonably -- because Scott reasonably believed that he could bump the car off the road at 90 miles an hour without risking the driver's life? Is that why it's like the Third Circuit case?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, but the Third Circuit case you just described didn't talk about intent. It talked about reasonable belief.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Before do you that, will you go back to the Philadelphia case. Do you contend that a jury could find that he reasonably believed that he would not cause, that he would not raise a serious risk of death or serious bodily harm by bumping the car at 90 miles an hour?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: I don't understand that. How could such a belief be reasonable? What am I missing here?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: That doesn't answer my question.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Why, why would it be reasonable to believe that a car could be bumped at 90 miles an hour plus without raising a substantial risk of death or serious bodily harm? How could such a belief be reasonable?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Some people are lucky. We're talking about creating a substantial risk. How would it be reasonable to assume that one would not create a substantial risk?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, that's a different issue and you may prevail on other arguments in the case. But as to whether or not there's a likelihood or a reasonable likelihood of serious injury, it seems to me that's clearly a question for the jury. I mean, we might argue about it up here, but that's classic jury question, isn't it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Mr. Savrin, one technique that Officer Scott asked permission to use was described as a PIT technique that would be a life and limb- sparing measure. One oddity about this case is that he called and asked permission to use that less risky method and yet when he determined that he couldn't do that, given the speed of the vehicles, he didn't ask permission to do what he did do, which was life-endangering.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Where is that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: And he said he gave permission for more than PIT procedure?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Well, the phrase used was "take him out," wasn't it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Does a police officer have any obligation in a situation like this to consider other alternatives, and if so what other alternatives might have been available to this officer?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: And even with letting him go, isn't it possible they could get other roadblocks up ahead or get other people involved in the attempt to catch him?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Isn't it true that there's no traffic on the road at that particular time?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Well, in that circumstance why wouldn't he just consider discontinuing the chase?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Would that have been likely if the officer had discontinued the chase?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, Mr. Savrin. Mr. Garre?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Does it matter exactly what the nature of the escape was? Are we supposed to evaluate whether this was reckless enough? Well, let's say the driver did not go off 90 miles an hour. Let's say he obeyed the speed limit. He just wasn't going to stop. Does that make it a different case?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: I would think that would apply to all high-speed cases; would you not agree?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Yes. But that was while he was being chased, right? Before being chased he hadn't done any of this. He was going 72 miles an hour in a 55-mile zone, isn't that right.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: No but if you're thinking of the likelihood of harm if they discontinued the chase, is it not reasonable to assume he might go back to going 72 miles an hour in a 55-mile zone?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SC ALIA
speakers.text: It would might also be reasonable to assume that anyone who was chased by the police will immediately speed up to 90 miles an hour.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SC ALIA
speakers.text: It doesn't seem to me a very good rule to give to police forces: Anybody who's going 72 miles an hour, let him go. Or at least if he hits 90, let him go.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: There isn't a question. There is a question of whether it justifies the use of deadly force, to prevent this -- this situation.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Why are these absolute? I mean I looked at Garner and then I looked at Graham and Graham which came later said that all claims that officers have used excessive force, deadly or not, should be analyzed under the Fourth Amendment and its reasonableness standard. So I guess-- isn't that right, isn't that the law?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: All right, if that's the law, then whether -- of course an automobile could, could kill people. Of course it can. So can a lot of things. But an automobile isn't a gun, and a chase on the highway is not a chase through a back yard, though both could end up with the person being chased dead. So aren't we supposed to look at all the circumstances, including the circumstance of what -- one that interests me, one, is that the right standard? Two, did Scott know that the reason he was chasing this person was because he had violated a speed limit, or was he ignorant of the reason why the individual was racing away at 90 miles an hour, which is as far as the record could show?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: And a reasonable juror could not conclude to the contrary?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Is it reasonable for him to suppose that there might be something more going on if the guy is trying this hard to get away from a speeding ticket? That presents he presents a danger to the community quite apart from the driving?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Is that a factor that goes into the analysis?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: What if they knew there were drugs in the car that he would dispose of if he had got caught. Would that justify this using deadly force?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: I'm rather clear it would not, isn't it? Because that would be no more serious than the crime in Garner, would it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But your position would be the same even if Scott knew that the only reason they were trying to stop him initially was the speeding violation?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Why, why wouldn't it matter? I mean, other things being equal, suppose that he known that all that happens, suppose he was two miles beyond the speed limit. And Scott knew the whole thing or Scott was the one who did it, and he says maybe he is a young kid who is frightened and he has his license number and he could get him later. I mean, why wouldn't it be nutty to -- to try to bump somebody off the road, when all, that's all that's at stake?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: How do you deal with the Brower case? That it was a 193 -- 83 action against the police for setting up a roadblock to catch a speeder. And the Court said that the roadblock was enough to give rise to a 1983 claim?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: May I just make this one point? Is it correct that the issue is whether it's reasonable or is the issue whether a jury could find it unreasonable?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, Mr. Garre. Mr. Jones.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Is there any doubt that Mr. Harris was likely to cause death or serious injury to the other cars on the highway that he was passing?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: We are not talking about driving in violation of traffic laws. We talking about 90 miles an hour on a two-lane highway, swerving past cars in the incoming traffic - -

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Hitting -- after hitting Officer Scott's car and continuing on. That's a little more than just unsafe.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: He used the turning signal. That's like the strangler who observes the no smoking sign. (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Mr. Jones, I looked at the videotape on this. It seemed to me that he created a tremendous risk of drivers on that road. Is that an unreasonable way of looking at the -- at this tape?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: He created the scariest chase I ever saw since "The French Connection." (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: It is frightening.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: A frightening amount of speed, and cars coming in the opposite direction, at night, on a two-lane windy road - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: The question was whether he was creating a substantial risk doing that.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: And my, my question is how could a jury find otherwise? Your answer up to this point is that well, he used signal lights and his reflexes were good, and they sure were. But the question is whether he was creating a substantial risk of death or serious bodily harm to others. And my question is leaving -- assuming that his reflexes were good and he knew how to use the signal lights, how could the jury fail to find that he was creating such a risk?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Garner was not talking about someone who at the time the deadly force was used was himself creating a substantial risk of death or serious bodily harm to others. That's what we are dealing with here. And the reasonableness of the officer's action depends on whether, at the summary judgment stage, a jury can reasonably find that, in fact, he was not creating at that moment, a substantial risk of serious bodily harm or death to others. And my question is, how could a jury find anything else?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Did Scott, know that? Did Scott -- Do you have evidence to show that Scott knew that the underlying offense was a speeding violation?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: And Scott has testified he didn't know it.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Now, do you think you can get to the jury on the question of whether he knew it.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I'd like a yes or no answer.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: That doesn't sound like yes or no.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: The question is, can you get to the jury on the question of whether Scott knew that the underlying offense was for speeding?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: All right. If Scott didn't know it, I mean, my goodness, then I don't see the relevance of whether it was speeding or not. And I was with you when I read the -- the opinion of the court below. And I read the other brief. I was on the other side. Then I've been shifting back and forth. Then I look at that tape, and I have to say that when I looked at the tape, my reaction was somewhat similar to Justice Alito's. And so if it's doubtful and then you can't even show that the person who did it knew that this was for speeding rather than for murder, how can you get to the jury?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, as the Chief Justice indicated through a question earlier, isn't it reasonable for an officer to assume that it is -- he is trying to escape because there is something more serious than speeding at stake? I mean, that's the assumption I would draw.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: You mean just as many people take off in high speed chases for speeding as for serious crimes?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: But at the moment Scott came into this case, what difference does that make? Why is that even relevant? Let's assume Scott knew that this entire situation had eventuated out of an 18 mile in excess of speed act by the individual. Assume that. What Scott also knew at the point at which he joined the chase was that this individual was driving a car at 90 miles an hour. He was crossing yellow lines, going through red lights, et cetera. At that point, wasn't the only legally relevant data whether or not Harris was creating the risk of death or bodily harm to others?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: So you agree that whether Scott knew or didn't know, that this whole scenario had eventuated out of a speeding situation was irrelevant?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: That's exactly where I started. And I wondered -- that's what I'm uncertain about the standard for this. Because as you and the others have been arguing, if the question is one about rules surrounding the use of deadly force. But then when I read what I read out to you, in Graham, it seemed to me that Graham, which comes after Garner, says that's not the standard. Graham is a standard of simple reasonableness and Garner is simply an illustration of that as applied to guns and a backyard chase, not as applied to cars which threaten other people much more.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Well, what is the standard? Am I supposed to apply -- am I not supposed to apply Graham?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: So you're saying I cannot do the following under the law, which would seem to be contrary to common sense, to say there is a big difference between a policeman shooting a person who is running away and threatens no harm to others, and a policeman using a gun -- using a car on a highway to try to get a person to stop who is threatening others. I have to treat those exactly as if they were the same thing.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: The Eleventh Circuit gave the exact opposite answer in the Adams case, which if you're looking at what the -- was clearly established law from the point of view of the officer that provides him guidance that the Garner case does not dictate a result in the use of deadly force in the police chase case involving an automobile.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: So when Officer Scott was trying to figure out what the law was, he should have relied on the dissent in the case?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Was there any case at the time of the action in this case, any decision that said ramming, ramming a car to end a chase violates the Fourth Amendment?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Brower was a roadblock case.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: But the issue in the case was quite simply whether there had been a seizure. Isn't that the issue?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Go ahead. Finish your - -

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: If I could just get back to an earlier point. You think what the officer should have done in this case was to let Mr. Harris go.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Even though he doesn't know at that point that he will ever be able to arrest him later. He doesn't know if it's a stolen car or not.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: And he doesn't know why he is being pursued, whether it's for mass murder or terrorism or anything else.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Once they have gotten away, I assume.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Not if he is shooting his way out of the house and endangering other people.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I mean, that's a factor here, of course. If he has taken the jewelry and he's gone off into the night, if shooting at him might endanger somebody else, or even kill him, you have to let him go. I'm talking about a burglar who is, you know, who is shooting as he leaves.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Of course you can shoot him.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Can you tell me as of the time he exited the parking lot, by that point, had he committed any felonies?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: 90 miles an hour would not be a felony, not a reckless driving?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Yes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: At no point did he commit a felony?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But he certainly committed a lot of - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: If he had intended to hit the police officer, was it - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: The key point is that he is endangering the lives and safety of others. Anyone who has watched that tape has got to come to that conclusion, looking at the road and the way that this car was swerving, and the cars coming in the opposite direction. This was a situation fraught with danger.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Is that a factual finding of the, of the trial court here?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Are we bound by that fact?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Even if having watched the tape, there is no way that, that factual finding can be accurate?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I don't see how -- I mean, you know, given our prior discussion here, I don't see how that's the issue. Because you say we have to assume that the Defendant here didn't know that, in fact, all that was at issue was a violation of the traffic law.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: That conduct -- it could be conduct -- you could say exactly your same question, just as the Chief just said. I mean, I don't know how to get around this. You could say the question was, does a person who reasonably thinks he might be being pursued for a murder - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: When someone is fleeing and creating a grave danger, let's just assume that that's the case, creating a very danger for other drivers on the road, when in your view is it reasonable for the police to use deadly force to stop that, as opposed to breaking off the chase? What, what is the test.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: How could you possibly give a warning in this situation?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Why wasn't there warning? There were lights, there were sirens. Surely the defendant knew that the police were trying to stop him.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: What am I -- you said factually. What am I supposed to assume? You said in light of -- I mean, I looked at the tape and that tape shows he is weaving on both sides of the lane, swerving around automobiles that are coming in the opposite direction with their lights on, goes through a red light where there are several cars that are right there, weaves around them, and there are cars coming the other way, weaves back, goes down the road. Now, what in fact -- am I supposed to pretend I haven't seen that? What am I supposed to pretend to here?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: You didn't see that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: You didn't -- I thought that -- you didn't see that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: No, no. I -- what I saw is he is driving down one lane, what I mean by weaving, and this lane goes with me in traffic. And there is some cars in front of him, so he goes in the other lane where the cars are now coming right directly at him. And then before they hit him, he goes back to the first lane and he does this while going through a red light, it seemed to me. Am I -- did I mis-see that? I'll go look at it again if you - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Yeah.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Well that's, that's what I wonder. If the court says that isn't what happened, and I see with my eyes that is what happened, what am I supposed to do?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: The district - - (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Under, under -- under your rule, what you're concerned with is the bumping, the use of the force. Under your rule, if the police continue the chase without using the, without trying to ram him, and then there is an accident and innocent people are killed, or injured, I assume that under the tort laws of most states, the police could be liable.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, aren't they the proximate cause if they continue the chase without trying to terminate it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: No. No. Well, I meant terminate the chase by -- by -- by forcing him off the road.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But isn't there -- but isn't that one way to assure that the police are not liable, both from a moral standpoint and a legal standpoint, for causing the injury of other people?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, you mean it's irrelevant to our analysis to consider that he might injure other people?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Mr. Jones, could I - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Could I ask whether the portion of the opinion that you say establishes that he was not endangering anybody is this portion? The court is mindful that traffic laws are designed to -- safely -- and Harris acted in an unsafe manner. However, the record reflects" -- - is this the portion?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- "that he maintained control over his vehicle." Well, that doesn't prove he's not endangering anybody. "Used his turn signals" -- wonderful. (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: "And did not endanger any particular motorist on the road." I think that's true. In that scary chase he, he didn't come close to hitting any particular car, but I don't think that's, that's a finding that he was not endangering anybody. "Any particular motorist," but he was endangering the public at large.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: It depends on how fast - - if depends on how fast the car is going, whether it's a two-lane road or four-lane divided highway. All those factors come into, into account. And it doesn't seem to me that we have to adopt a rule that will, that will discourage police officers. There's, there's enough disincentive to engage in this kind of activity in the fact that the police officer may hurt himself. It's pretty risky to conduct this kind of a maneuver, don't you think? I wouldn't have done it if I was Scott.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I would have let the guy go.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Driving 90 miles an hour and comes up, approaches that car, that car swerved. Scott could have been killed, couldn't he?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: So I don't think we need a whole lot of disincentive to stop police officers in engaging in frolicsome conduct.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Let me just ask this question. In trying to assess the likelihood of harm to innocent people who would be hurt by this by this guy driving so fast, is that, do we measure it by assuming that the chase will continue? Or do we measure it by assuming that the chase would be discontinued?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Just as we did in Garner?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: If it were -- clear that a jury could find that there would be no unreasonable risk to innocent motorists if they discontinued the chase - - assume that's a possible finding. If that were true, would there be a duty to discontinue the chase?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: You're saying there is a duty not to use deadly force.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: And aren't you concerned that that creates an incentive in every case for anyone who, that sees the blue lights behind them to know that all they have to do is keep fleeing and the police are going to have to give up eventually?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, Garner - - Garner was the case involving shooting the guy in the back, right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But your, your answer to Justice Stevens as I understand it was the police not have the duty to discontinue the chase? The obverse of that is that the police may prolong the chase, i.e., prolong the injury to the public. I'm surprised at your answer.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: It is certainly the case that if there is going to be a, a risk of deadly harm to innocent third parties, there would be a duty to discontinue the chase rather kill him. But you don't seem to buy that.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Did this study show what future fleeing speeders would do? I mean, I will accept that for, for the sake of argument that -- in fact, it's probably true. I would have guessed that, if the police stopped chasing, you don't go 90 miles an hour anymore. But did this study show what the effect of a rule that says stop chasing when he hits 85, what the effect of that rule would be on, on fleeing speeders or fleeing felons, or fleeing anybody?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, Mr. Jones. Mr. Savrin, you have four minutes remaining.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: What am I supposed to do? I mean, I'll look again at the tape. I certainly will do that. But suppose I look at the tape and I end up with Chico Marx's old question with respect to the Court of Appeals: Who do you believe, me or your own eyes?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Whether he is endangering anybody is a historical fact, no? So what do you do about that finding?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: It is.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: What is the, the court saying -- and this is on page 39 A of the petition appendix -- when Harris was driving away from officers and when there, when there were no other motorists or pedestrians nearby, thus casting doubt on defendant's assertion that at the time of the ramming, Harris posed an immediate threat of harm to others. This is a finding that there were no other motorists or pedestrians nearby when the ramming occurred.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I would hope he would wait until there were no pedestrians or vehicles coming before he, before he did the ramming.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I assume he waited precisely for that kind of a gap in the traffic?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Do you agree with Mr. Jones' statement that none of Mr. Harris' conduct rose to the level of a felony?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, Mr. Savrin. The case is submitted. [Whereupon, at 11:47 a.m., the case in the above-titled matter was submitted.]
